newsitem.title: MALDIVES: S.Asian nations vow to have free trade by 2001.
newsitem.headline: S.Asian nations vow to have free trade by 2001.

text.p: Seven South Asian nations, frustrated over slack cross-border commerce, decided on Tuesday to advance a deadline for forming a free trade area by four years to 2001, Indian Prime Minister Inder Kumar Gujral said.

Gujral told a news conference on a resort island in the Maldives that leaders of the South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation (SAARC) reached the decision on the second day of a three-day summit.
The seven-nation SAARC had previously agreed to form the South Asian Free Trade Area (SAFTA) preferably by 2000, but no later than 2005.
"We have agreed that the introduction of SAFTA should be accelerated to 2001 as the target year," Gujral said.

The SAARC member states -- Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Maldives, Nepal, Pakistan and Sri Lanka -- will commit themselves to the new deadline in a joint declaration to be issued at the conclusion of the summit on Wednesday, Gujral said.
The SAARC leaders met at the Kurumba Village beach resort, a tiny island in the sparkling necklace of 1,190 islands that make up the Maldives, the host nation and smallest member of the bloc.

SAARC leaders have openly lamented the slow pace of economic integration in the South Asian region, where the annual per capita income of $309 lags behind even sub-Saharan Africa's $555, according to the Islamabad-based Human Development Centre.
Trade within the region's states, which have 1.2 billion people -- one fifth of the world's population -- still accounts for only three percent of SAARC's total world trade.
At this week's meeting, SAARC leaders openly expressed disappointment over the slow pace of regional integration, especially in trade and investment.
Pakistani Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif urged member states at Monday's opening meeting to "wake up from the slumber of inaction".

Maldivian President Maumoon Abdul Gayoom, SAARC's new chairman, called for more political dialogue, while Sri Lankan President Chandrika Kumaratunga suggested more frequent, informal and confidential talks among SAARC leaders.
Gujral said the leaders had agreed to set up a 15-member "eminent persons group" to lauch a review to revitalise the bloc.
The Indian leader said it was also agreed that SAARC representatives would meet more often, dispensing with much of the ceremony and adopting a more informal format in order to build closer ties.
Gujral said the SAARC declaration would call for fresh efforts to promote education, lend support to female children and halt the trafficking of women and child prostitution.

The opening day of the summit was dominated by a meeting between the prime ministers of the region's two biggest states, India and Pakistan, whose rivalry has frustrated SAARC's efforts to pull the region out of poverty.
